A lot of nostalgia is born from things we experienced as children. Being a child has its cons, but life was much simpler back then, wasn't it? Not only that, but we ourselves had more innocence and purity. So, when I hear Bad Day or Shut Up!, I'm taken back to my childhood for a little, and I long for those days when my biggest problems were school and "what am I going to wear to my friend's house?"

Nowadays, I have to think about a lot of stuff. I have responsiblilities, I need reminders, I have to do this and that if I want to succeed. In a way, nostalgia is like medicine that was built in. Just a little something that could help us get through the day

This isn't the case for everyone, though. Many people have had poor childhoods, so they would rather not think about them. Instead, their nostalgia may stem from a desire, not to go back to the past and relive it, but CHANGE it

I’m 23, and for all you teens out there, I have one piece of advice. When you go somewhere for a few days that you know is gonna be one of the best things you’ll do for a while, (for example, for me, it was a school football tour with my mates, and a trip to Germany with my best friends), listen to 4 or 5 songs only, whenever you have the time in that trip. They don’t have to be songs that u love, and u can do other things while you’re listening.

What that did for me was, whenever I listened to those songs in the future, I had such nostalgia. Please, just try it.

nostalgia and PTSD are one in the same. Its a chemical released in your brain that was triggered by your environment. As your growing up your brain is creating recognizable patterns from your environment but when it comes to life or death your brain will try and remember the entire experience even if it happens once a year or ten years. Also do you think you make your our choices or the environment around you tell you what to do. We have our ancestors to thank for this trait. Thousands of years ago humans were scavengers and had to focus on finding food and water 24/7 all the while trying to keep them safe from danger and the brain cant handle being on alert 24/7 at the same time of gathering food and sleeping. So the brain will allow you to live focusing on food and reproduction and be able to make a split second choice can be made when danger has snuck up on you when your eating berries or seeds and not get killed by a predator. Vsauce did you make the choice to make this video or were you just doing what your environment said to do?

I never heard it referred to as "the game", nor did I think that there were that many people other than myself who played said game with themselves, in fact I had to check the comments to see what he meant because at first I thought he was referring to "the quiet game", but I do have this little thing I've done ever since I was a little kid in cub scouts, and I had a funny daydream about how I was so comfortable with nature that even if someone popped up and said "Spiders in your tent!" It still wouldn't bother me, since I always loved daddy long legs all over the inside of our old army tents. And eeeever since then, for some odd reason, I found it funny when I would later remember that daydream, and would not only realize how suprisingly long it had been since I'd last remembered it, but I'd also always be able to recall roughly when/where I'd last thought of it.. I I think it just seemed such a simple and easy to recall concept, especially given how often I went camping, that I figured the odds of me going any significant time without recalling it one way or another were next to nothing, that I guess I would find it amusing when every so often I'd remember it, and realize it'd been 6 months, or two years, or in this case, 4 years - in my previous home, on my balcony watching someone pack their Subaru, and I thought of it for the first time in over a year. So, that was the longest I've gone, so far..!
And only because I read the comments, and realized that it was essentially the same "game" I'd been playing for 20+ years! Alone, I'd thought!

About the false memories thing: I think it is more likely that people trust the researchers who show them the fake photos, so even if they don't remember what happened in the photos they assume the photos must be real, and try to think of a real event in their lives they remember that could plausibly be depicted in the photos.

I literally had nostalgia for what happened several weeks ago, it was that recent.

Also, for all the people who think nostalgia feels bad and its an unpleasant emotion, understand that we will all have access to our past, just like in a time machine, when we die, it is called a ''life review'', looked it up, it is part of many near death experiences people have had.

Also in the afterlife there are the Akashic records, a place where all the lives of everybody is stored, so you have that which you can access to get info from the past , and maybe relieve the ''glory days''.

Also when i feel nostalgia i literally feel exactly what i felt in the past, the same emotion, identical, so when people say things werent as good as you remember them i disagree, because by feeling nostalgia you are reliving the past.

Also it is interesting to note that every nostalgic memory is unique and feels different. Thats how i would describe nostalgic memories, as having a UNIQUE feeling from the past, relived.

Whenever I try to sleep I get suicide thoughts, they gets stronger and stronger as I get older. It's kinda like having a song stuck in your head. But soon now I think it's time to get rid of this repetitive tune. I honestly don't see any other way out of it, and frankly, I don't know if I want any other way out. What's the point of living when there is nothing more positive to look forward to? All you live for is to pay the bills, dissapoint friends and family, and work your ass off to earn money to pay more bills... And at the end of it all, you just sit there alone in the dark with nothing, just some dead material things you have lost interest in. I have long ago stopped answering the phone when strange numbers calls me, I probably have unpaid bills, or the landlord wants to kick me out, or someone I haven't seen in years wants to talk to me. I don't bother anyway, I have nothing I want to say or talk about, I know life ain't fair, but it should at least be somewhat enjoyable, but instead it's all depression, paranoia, money and expectations. If I could go live as a hermit out in the woods, alone, just living of the nature, in peace, I would very much be a happy man. But even that is a far out goal regarding my current situation. And the only reason I haven't cleaned out my skull already, is because I am an only child and my parents are separated, but still close friends, yet I don't want them to grow old alone with no one close to take care of them, I am the only one they have. Yet, I feel horrible just going through the motion every day, trying to stay invisible, keep for myself as these darks thoughts are decaying me from inside, making me barley motivated to get up in the morning and keeping me from having a single night of normal sleep. On Sunday I turn 30, I really hope I'll be dead by then. This song has been stuck in my head now for over a decade, maybe even closer to half my life... You might call me weak for not going through with it already, maybe I am, or maybe I am strong to keep on trucking through this crap and subconscious wishing things will pick up? But, no matter, it doesn't change the fact that it has worn me quite down.

The only thing I have good recall for is what I was listening to at almost any age/time in my life... I have always wondered why I had those severe memory problems, it’s really weird & freaks me out. Why do I get nostalgic for things from other people’s memory that they told me about?

When I was a very little girl, I loved Barney's Great Adventure. I would always watch that movie with Grandma whenever she came over to visit. At the ending of the movie, me and Grandma will always hug whenever they sang I Love You. When I was 11 years old, Grandma died. She was only 62 years old, which is so freakishly young. I forgot all about the movie, but I still loved it. When I was 15 years old and in high school, I remembered Barney's Great Adventure and the nostalgia from that movie hit me hard like a truck when I was in the school library with my friends. One of my friends said, "Hannah, are you okay? You seem upset about something." And then I told him, "I'm fine. I'm just a little tired." Then he said, "then rest." And then I said, "you don't understand." Then one of my other friends asked me, "are you having monthly girls' things?" And then I said, "no. My 8 days are up and by the way, this is much much worse than that." And then she asked, "are you pregnant?" And then I said, "no. I'm not married. I don't even have a boyfriend." And then one of my best friends asked me, "did you get into a fight with your family?" Then I said, "no." I put my head down on the table. Then I said, "that movie. Oh my goodness, that movie!" And then my friend, who was the guy who asked me if I was okay, said, "what movie is it? Is it Titanic? Twilight? ET?" And then I said, "neither. It's a movie that I loved to watch with Grandma when I was a very little girl." And then my friend said, "what's the movie called?" And then I said, "I don't remember what the movie is called, but I remember the ending." And then he said, "Hannah, why don't you call your grandmother and tell her to come to your house so you two can watch this movie together just likw old times?" And then I said, "I can't do that." And then he said, "why?" And then, I said, "Grandma died when I was 11 years old." And then, my teacher told all of us that I was experiencing nostalgia. I asked her what nostalgia is and she told us what it means.

The claim about 'it takes about 5 years replace all of atoms in your body' is not true:


https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/does-body-replace-itself-seven-years/?fbclid=IwAR0I9iVAkpyOIjMLhIdGpFpRyr_53PfoXx1mgYg4PUd7agGcplJMA4TgMi0


"The researcher behind a groundbreaking study that attempted to date the ages of various cells in a human body, Jonas Frisen, famously estimated that the average age of a cell in the human body is between 7 and 10 years old in a pivotal 2005 paper published in Cell.

These statements have led some to the conclusion that every cell in the human body is replaced every 7 to 10 years — a fun but inaccurate factoid commonly held as true. The central flaw in the argument is that an average of all the cells in a body masks the fact that some cells last very long times, and other cells don’t regenerate for a person’s entire lifetime, as described by NPR:

It turns out that each body part has its own very distinct lifespan. The lining of the stomach, constantly under assault by digestive acid, is renewed every few days. But bones are refreshed once a decade. And there are a few parts of you that stay with you from birth to death.

I heard nostalgia is the process of mourning lost futures. You were alive in that moment in lets say 1995, or 2001 or 2011, listening to your favourite song. But in that moment there was a life path, that you were just so sure you were on. In a moment of clarity, when you now listen to that old song again, you remember that path you thought you were on back then, when you used to listen to that particular song all the time... and you realise you went in a completely different direction.


It is almost certain you went on another path than the approximate one you imagined you were on back then, as your young inexperienced brain at that time was making a poor estimation of what's likely in the future, mix that with the unpredictable change of culture over the time span between then and now (you probably hadn't accounted for it back then either) and then finally mix all that with the change in your own tastes... these changes likely lead you on a completely different path and since that time you have lived a very different life from the one you thought you would lead. Your values are different, your emotions are different, the job you do, the relationships you have. All different. That is fine.


But all those hopes and dreams that you never did realize, there wasn't a day when you said goodbye to them all. Some were altered, some were replaced, most you forgot until your whole world view was radically different, it happened just a little bit, day by day. When you hear that bit of music though and suddenly it's 2011 again, and suddenly you're in your first apartment, with that partner, the one you'd always meet at that bar that doesn't exist anymore, and who you keep in touch with back then on a form of media that is no longer used, you remember that old path you thought you were on, it was simplistic and comforting seeming, you realise it has completely vanished and was a mere fiction that existed in a fleeting moment. You miss your belief in it. You mourn the future you thought you'd be living in that never came to fruition. You mourn lost futures.


And the future you now imagine you will have over the next 10 years... it will turn out totally differently too. And then you will miss the future you imagine you'll have now, in 2019, when its 2029! And you will call this time simpler and be sad for it's passing. And then you'll repeat it again!

It's dark outside, but I remember... All the family vacations, the most embarrassing moments on the playground in grade 3, all the friends you've spent hours laughing with that you haven't seen in 5 years... I think that one major reason why we feel nostalgia is simply because there is something in our past that we yearn for.
My reason to feel nostalgic is because I had lots of friends back in junior high school that I would usually hang out with, and this made me feel much more "grounded", so to speak.
I lost contact with a lot of those people after junior high school and then had problems finding a new group anywhere close to that again, and right now I have maybe 2 friends that I might hang out with on sporadic occasions, and that's not the same thing.
This has also made me become a lot less social in general.

I have noticed that I feel encouraged when I listen to some of the music that I heard back then, since it makes me reconnect with my old personality from back then a little bit.
Eurodance songs seem to make a great impact on me, especially songs like "Sweet Dreams" by La Bouche.
Really makes me feel like I am back at some junior high school disco in the 90s and hanging out with all those old friends again.

I was born in the nineties, and I felt nostalgia for:
Iron age / The middle ages (medieval)
Stone age
Jurassic age
Bronze age (Rome)
Antique (Egypt /Arabic World)
Cold War age
Pirate age (15th + 16th century)
Steam(punk) age (18th century) and
Electricity age (19th century)
With the beginning of the last century (Hollywood age)
Even ages that hasn't been happened / yet
(Cyberpunk, Fantasy Worlds, Utopia like Atlantis, Distopia like Star Wars / Beyond Good and Evil 2 - that game hasn't even been out yet)
Or even with places I've never been (as of yet) like Japan which would be referred to wanderlust (Fernweh) the counterpart to homesickness (Heimweh)

But actually LIVING in those times and places is a whole different story. Most of them were fucked up and just filled with war or bad conditions. I wouldn't want to live there! :D

It's good that it's just nostalgic, and that we can experience this with movies and games in my opinion :)

This is why I love Retro Games so much. They give us a change to dive into the nostalgia EXACTLY AS IT WAS. Normally with self-experienced nostalgia it's hard to do. You can try to replace the old times with wearing the same hair style, with making a fire on your chimney, drinking some tea, reading the same book or watching the same movie etc. But with gaming it's like you were in that world again. Of course it was better when you played it back then but it still gives me the goosebumps and shivering when I hear the sound effects and watching the cutscenes etc. of MGS3.

You can't just dive into the 18th century or medieval or the 60s like the channels Townsends, Steve1989MREInfo and other are trying to. But I think it's better like that because actually LIVING in those times wasn't as good, as the nostalgic feeling is.

Hey Michael, you touched on music in your video and I would like to propose a view more questions for you elaborate on. I understand the communal church clapping reinforcing a feeling of oneness, dancing in raves probably similar, line - dancing being the ultimate form of submission, and the many ethnic and religious dancing in a circle to strengthen bonds. then there's dancing "to express your self" to go against the grain (break dancing, voguing et.). The reason I am asking is that I am a producer and I write music for myself. If I hit a groove my body starts convulsing uncontrollably but in sync with the beat, I know I've hit on something special, the lizard brain perhaps. Music I write with rules and regulations, a goal enforced by tradition and expectations... usually end up as top of the pops... but they lack "soul". You see where I am going with this? thanks, Michael, big fan, as always.

I've had some nostalgic feelings that kinda ended up being so intense they hurt me, but if there's anyone out there that feels the same, there's tow things that can really help you. (They worked for me)

The first way is to have something, no matter how small it is, to always look forward to. So like a small trip with your family next month or a night out with your friends Friday or finally being done with that exam coming up- anything, big or small.
And the second thing is to do something that makes you feel alive, that makes you glow, that makes you feel in the moment and have that happy-go-lucky smile on your face, not caring about past fears or hurts or worrying about the future. And for me, that is usually just being with my family and talking to them, they make me feel so alive and happy to be with them. Talking to friends does the same, and so does anything to do with going outside, like mountain biking or taking a walk with someone.

Just doing those two things, ACTUALLY trying to do them, helps so much. they make you excited to live again. :)

Nostalgia makes me really sad and depressed, missing what happened then and that it will never happen again. There were things that mad me happy or mad back then, but now? I don't even remember those things. The things that make me happy or mad will be constantly changing and I will never experience those experiences ever again. This may seem dark but, I wish and hope that in the afterlife we are able to replay moments in our life and feel what we felt, see what we saw, smell what we smelt, touch what we touched, taste what we tasted, and hear what we heard. Those may seem insignificant but when I smell certain things, I sometimes am reminded that I have smelt that before. That I have seen that before, touched that before, heard that before, tasted that before. If I get my wish and hope is fulfilled, I will find what made me, and find what made me feel that way. At times I watch an old video or old youtuber and realize that the world will never be what it was. I know that probably didn't make sense whatsoever but I needed to say it. Actually you just really helped me to understand one of the major problems of modern culture! This point of view (which is what it is) that you are presenting, would once have been posed by a philosophy student as a point of view and then critically challenged or dissected. But because you present it as fact, and because the world of youtube has very little in the way of effective cross-referencing, there is no counterpoint presented to your views. September 15, 2009 - October 31, 2013. I'm 18 and I'm always thinking about something, be it music or memories from that time. I first heard Stand Up and Scream and that blew my mind. The time when I went to my first homecoming dance and that homecoming game when my best friend introduced me to Tyler, the Creator; life-changing moments...Those were the times before the artists I used to love peaked, life was a thrill, and music was good. I almost feel as if I should've graduated in 2012 or 2013 and that I was born in the wrong generation. I'm stuck there I guess...I just got home from my senior prom, and I'm scared for the future. All those bands have since sold out for money, faces have grown old, and I regret some things that I never did. I look back on where I've been and realize that what all I've ever known; school, friends, family, will sadly soon come to an end. I'll have to move on, and let it go, but I'm just not sure I'm ready yet.

I remember recording my friends, a cousin of mine, and myself on cassette tapes as we played Ninja Turtle games on my old Nintendo with each other and, again, later on, when I got hooked on Donkey Kong Country for Super NES. The tone shared between us was one of pure, unadulterated, joy, non-stop laughs and being totally lost in the moment, free from fears of any kind. Those tapes would become a powerful reminder, to an older self, of who I was capable of being, if only I could live in the moment again, if only I could recapture the courage (carelessness) that I had at the time.

I think I threw out the last tape (mostly out of embarrassment) about 10 years ago and it saddens me to this day that I decided to remove that connection to a past that felt so much purer and real. It really feels like I threw a part of myself away on that day.

You'd think that the older self would have the most useful lessons to share with the young pup when presented with the time machine opportunity, but, in my case, this old man would be quietly attentive to the advice of his younger self, and the young pup wouldn't have to say one damn word for me to benefit from the experience. All I'd need is for him to get lost in his joy, like he did so often in those years, and I'd come back a stronger man for having witnessed it again, from my new perspective.

Oh, how I hope that I can rewind my life like a movie when I die so that I can relive those moments of purity. Of course, I wouldn't stop at my experiences with video games. I'd definitely revisit my relationships with my parents, grandparents, other relatives, and friends during that period of my life . Everything was so much more alive and engaging. I want it again like a drug; like a heroin addict - shoot it straight into my veins so that I can feel alive again!

If there's a God, then it will happen. Fingers crossed :)

This is my theory: Nostalgia is actually your body remembering a time when you felt happy or safe, so when the nostalgia is triggered (usually in a state in which you are long enough past or away from the original event), that is your body saying that thats where you need to run back to if you are ever feeling in danger. It's a simple evolutionary tactic. It makes sense because a lot of instances of people experiencing nostalgia is when they go from child to adult. adult hood is where you are more aware and knowledgable about dangers and where you feel most uncomfortable. Childhood, for the majority, was when you had no worry, and were very ignorant and in general more happy. because of this you long for when you were happy and that just happens to be mostly your childhood. Maybe children take in events as being more important, thus making the memory more prominent in later years which could also be why childhood is where most nostalgic memories come from.

There is some evidence to suggest that dancing can be linked to our 'fight or flight' mechanisms. When we listen to music is changes all sorts of physical process - heart rate, respiration, blood pressure, perspiration - but most importantly, it signals the adrenal gland to release adrenaline. I have often heard from my friends that I remember amazingly much, and can explain much more detailed about my life from early age, from age 3 (maybe even 2) to age 9-10, which seems to be the age people often do not remember much from. I often ask  my brothers and friends "do you remember when we used to_____". But they often neglect, sometimes they recall.

I've always thought that was because they just didn't care, until a friend of me, who knows a little about psychology like me, told me that he has always noticed how detailed I am when I tell about things that we have done as kids, and that I actually DO remember more than many other people, and that's why they often don't share the same memories as me..   of course I myself has naturally assumed that my recollection of memory was average and normal, since I only have access to my own mind. And that's the only mind I know how works!

I find that I am MUCH more prone to nostalgia because of this, and I seem to be more more in "the 90s" compared to my friends. :)

i get ear worms every day, multiple times a day. even if it's not an ear worm, i just hear music all day every day, even in the background of my inner monologue or if i'm talking to people. it used to be a lot louder and harder to fade into the background. it became really hard for me to focus in some classes like math when we'd have work time in complete silence. the music would get so loud in my mind and i couldn't seem to stop it or focus on my work. when i started playing guitar, it got easier and not as loud. now i play 7 instruments and while the music is still always there, it isn't overwhelming like it used to be. every now and then though it gets like that again, and i'll get really annoying, almost never ending ear worms. i've noticed this usually happens if i haven't really played much for a few days or not at all. playing an instrument calms my mind and helps me think. this is one of the reasons it saddens me when i hear of music cuts in schools.

I felt almost like crying about missing WoW.  I remember when I looted my first silver.  I thought I was the richest person ever in my first minutes of WoW 10 years ago when I was 7.  I then have a flash back of this guy that stole the loot of the treasure chest in the Gurubashi arena. I cried after he took the loot, as if he stole it from me.  I then happened to get the loot later telling him "I'll just wait here for the next one."  When really, I didn't even know when the next one had spawned.  I ended up getting the Gurubashi arena grand master achievement.

I remember when I was first introduced to Swifty from people who were talking about him.  Everyone thought he was the best warrior ever because of his videos on YouTube.  I then remember when I was leveling with a warrior in Un'goro Crater, and he was a good friend of mine that I never saw again after he logged randomly.  I also remember my brother playing and I just logged in today from his account. There was characters in the guild that have not been online for 6+ years.  Then, I saw his guild info, and he barely spelled the words correctly that he put in.  I just feel so nostalgic about the past, and listening to this music for some reason.  I played Oblivion and Halo back then, but I don't have any nostalgic feeling for it for some reason.  My WoW journey has finally come to an end.  I just wanted to ask for 3 days of game time from a GM to dwell in the past for one last time.

I think we are how we are arranged. I mean for example- all protons and neutrons and electrons are same. It's how they are ARRANGED that matters. 2 protons and neutrons and 2 electrons make a helium atom. The same particles form oxygen when they come together as 8 neutrons, protons and electrons. I think it's the same way with memories....like memories are not 'stored' anywhere but merely links between neurons. A path say suppose neuron A to B to C is a memory, while neuron B to C to A is another memory. I think that;s what we are. A pattern, a unique arrangement of particles.

nostalgia often makes me feel both sad and amazed at how fast my life seems to be passing by. my earliest memories date back to preschool, and i can remember a lot from then on of my life (which is  over a decade worth of memories). i think back to things that occurred in fifth grade, in eighth grade, and even just last year, and i often find myself feeling amazed at how everything happened so quickly. i think about how different i was in the past, i think about the thoughts and feelings i must've had in certain moments of my past and try to relive them...but it feels like it all happened in a different lifetime, i don't feel like it was me who experienced those things. it's kind of mind-blowing really, i can't quite put it into words.

Interesting. I rarely feel nostalgic, but I suspect that is because my autobiographical memory isn't very strong. I have friends whose autobiographical memory is amazingly strong, and they tend to be more sentimental and nostalgic than me. I am a compulsive journaler, so the lack of autobiographical memory isn't usually a problem. I can be a killjoy when I point out what I wrote down about life events to others. The false memory principal seems to be pervasive in most people, so I don't rely on memory alone when talking about the past.

An interesting fact about earworms: Earworms are pieces of a rhythm that we have heard and liked, and our brain seeks complete patterns, or rhythms. So, there are two ways to get rid of an earworm.
1. Distract your mind from it.
2. Complete the rhythm by memorizing the song or beat.

I understand what you guys are trying to say about reminiscence bump. But I have to a correction to state about it. Reminiscence bump isn't your childhood it's actually the times in one's lifetime in which great changes occur (usually from ages 10-30). When you remember times before that (the times that vsauce is actually referring to in this video is actually infantile amnesia (times from birth to age 9 in which false and true memories exists due to the brain ). I think one thing that might explain some of the people in the "False Memory" case is that when they are shown the photoshopped photo of themselves, they make up a story to try and not "Fail" the test, or disappoint what others are expecting of them; Or at least, that is what they think others are thinking. Not that they know that it is a photoshopped picture, but the fact that they simply don't remember.

Trust me, we all know someone who believes they are right about EVERYTHING, even when they were wrong a minute ago, they'll say "I knew that."
It's a similar kind of thing. "I know what happened better than you do." or "I know everything that happened in my life."
There are not very many honest people in this world (Don't even get me started on people and their fake persona they put up about themselves.), so I believe that this is a big issue in the "False Memory" case, or at least with some of the people who were tested.

Nostalgia is a greek word (Νοσταλγία written in greek). It is a combination of two words from the ancient greek language: "Νόστος"(Nostos) and "Άλγος" (Algos). The first word means "home", where you come from. The second word means "Pain". Nostalgia means "Your pain (in that case it means "urgent need") to return home". You can search it up, if you want :-). This is what the word means. So every time we have this feeling is to return to a situation we were. A situation we had strong feelings for

The catchy music nowadays is mixed into the same frequencies as the frequency of, say, a baby crying or a cat meowing for food (sly creatures, cats). That's why we respond to it so well, 'cause we're programmed to recognize them immediately and do something about it. But because it keeps us on alert all the time, and almost all the pop songs are mixed this way, they make us irritable and moody. Sometimes even aggressive. That's why I love older music, I guess. I had something I wanted to add to this. I recently had the urge to listen to "Breaking the Habit" by Linkin Park, and when I listened to it again I had a rush of nostalgia. The thing is, at the time I was into this kind of music I was severely depressed and felt like I had no purpose in life. I was wondering, "Why would I feel positive emotions when harkening back to such a low point in my life?" My conclusion after watching this is that either I was feeling nostalgic about the escapist solace I was originally looking for in this music, or the fact that I can look back on that time in my life and realize how much I have improved emotionally and as a person in general. Or maybe it's a bizarre combination of the two, I can't be sure.

in my eyes anything can be a song but only certain sounds can be music. as much as different people have different definitions of "fun" different people have different ideas for what music is. personally (like i said above) i think the words "song" and "music" mean 2 different things. in my eyes the word 'song' can be any group or assortment of musical instruments, vocals and or any sound that can be made. the word "music" (again in  my eyes) means any sound or assortment of sound that is pleasant to the ears. by this logic music can be different things to different people, for example someone can listen to pop music and find it pleasant while others think of "pop" as a horrid noise that should be turned off immediately. also by this logic any sound can be a song whether it be the buzz of a bee to the sounds of gunshots. but sounds can be classified into 2 groups "noise" and music. in other words the "turn it off": group, or the "sing along while looking like an idiot and not caring :3" group.

Michael, you sure cover lots of material! I have always been interested in nostalgia, largely around music, but also in general. I think that nostalgia can be a nice feeling, but also that some people can become trapped in it, and that even good memories can trap us. When you spoke of "false memories," it made me think of what I call "vicarious nostalgia," which is basically longing for someone else's past as if I'd lived it myself. In any case, nostalgia can seem like a quagmire, preventing us from moving forward. I think that it can keep some people from taking risks.

I'm a composer writing a couple of trios whose focus is nostalgia. The first trio—"Suffusion"—is about that bogged down sense of nostalgia, while the second, "Ascent" will be a sort of liberation from that.  http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/composenberg/ascent-banff-residency-fund is my Kickstarter that describes it, and yes, this is a bit of a shameless plug. But as I am someone who both suffers and benefits from nostalgia, your video spoke to me. I'm interested in how music works that way, and whether music-as-nostalgia can somehow itself be expressed in a piece of music.

That's interesting.. but there's also another kind of nostalgia that hasn't anything to do with your actual memories or experience. I don't know if you can call it nostalgia but people sometimes call it Golden Age Mentality, or just generally a nostalgia for a time or place you've never lived in, and it's often idealised like regular nostalgia. I sometimes get nostalgic for 20's Paris or, oddly enough I've been told, for Soviet times, even though I was born a few years after the collapse of the USSR... So what's that about? it's not really about memory, and it's not just a general fondness for the time, but a genuine profound nostalgia.

The subject pronoun "I" follows other peoples' names when a noun phrase is a part of the subject of a larger sentence. When the first-person pronoun is used in conjunction with a second-person eponym like "James" in an object phrase then you use "myself." You never use first-person pronouns BEFORE second-person eponyms in a noun phrase and you never use "me" unless the first-person pronoun acts alone in the phrase.

Sorry for being prescriptivist but that is just how proper English speech works.

"Aging" outside the US and Canada is actually to do with psychology.  Ageing happens as when cells replicate they do so with small genetic errors.  Later, two erroneous cells will eventually merge and create further imperfections.  This degradation continues until we slowly ail.

Because the process isn't instantaneous. Its not like one day, every five years all the atoms in your body are miraculously swapped with brand spanking new ones. I don't know the precise answer to your specific question but I do know why we never sound like 'us' in recordings. Because we don't. When we hear ourselves speak we hear it from the where the ears are located, that is behind the resonance chamber of the mouth and nose. When that sound comes out everyone else hears a different noise to the voice we think we have! (I suspect our voices sounding terrible on tape is something to do with poor compression and badly set EQ)

comment_text: This is putting "Nostalgica Critic" videos on my reccomended list...

When we speak, our voice comes from inside our throat, the vocal chords to be specific. The vibrating of the vocal chords slightly alters what you hear, so your voice is a little less accurate when you hear yourself speak. However, this altered version is what you have become used to, because you've heard it your entire life. When you hear a more accurate representation of your voice, it sounds odd to you because that's not what you're used to. Hope that helps (:

The reason why you might not of heard yourself sound the same irl and in a recording can be caused by the quality of a mic (a high quality mic can go for 1000s of dollars) and the quality and accuracy of speakers (which again, can thin your wallet really quickly.) why do people hate their voice? --> vsauce

When you speak, you don't actually hear your voice. What you "hear" is not anything you hear. Rather, your jawbone's motions are interpreted by your brain when you speak and are "translated" into sound mentally, and this interpretation is often deeper. When you hear yourself on recordings, that's your actual voice.
Why people hate it is the same reason why people hate pictures of themselves. They're so used to seeing themselves in a reflection that camera photos seem unusual and out of place.
James May! Top Gear! I love that guy...

It's because we hear our voice from inside our head, not from a distance. The sound waves haven't traveled very far when we hear ourselves speak, so we're used to the effect of the inside of our mouths and skulls on our voices. On most recordings, your voice is just the way everyone else hears it, because the recording device is outside of your head. We probably dislike the way our voices sound on recordings because we've heard the warped version of our voices for our entire lives.

Melanin expression.

Melanin is the molecule responsible for making up the skin pigments. The least melanin they express, the clearer is their skin tone. The more they express, the darker is their skin tone. Diseases, such as vitiligo, affect the melanin-producing cells, melanocytes, in this case making the cells unable to function, and therefore, ceasing melanin function. That's what happened to Michael Jackson. On the other side of the coin, there's melanoma, responsible for skin spots.

My friend told me once that the reason why music gets stuck in our head is that we can't remember the end of the song. Since we can't remember the end, our brain keeps "playing" the song in our head, because it doesn't think the song is over yet. This also happens with really short tunes, because we are expecting more, and since it is really short, there IS no more, so the same problem happens.

This depends on how its deleted. All storage devices are chopped into little boxes. on the device there is also a sort of table of contents, which lists what is stored in what box, and which boxes are readdy to be overwritten. When you delete something, all you really do is add the number of the boxes your something was stored in to the list of boxes that can be overwritten. This means that it is still there until something new is saved on that exact spot. On thumbdrives and ssd's its different.

Our brains have evolved over time to reward us when we eat food that has a lot calories since we need the energy to survive. Fat has 9 Calories per gram while protein and carbs only have 4 per gram, making fat the most efficient way to get the energy we need to survive, so our brains will reward us more if we eat fatty foods than if we eat foods that are high in carbs or protein. Healthy foods are higher in carbs and protein while unhealthy foods are high in fat, so unhealthy food tastes better.

It's like the atoms in our brain are a big game of chess, and sometimes when pieces are on the board too long, they get "dirty" and have to be replaced, but with the same exact piece. So our memories are actually physically replaced with clones of themselves in a way, but we cannot comprehend them being clones because it is your brain's main function to comprehend things.

The cells that make up your body die. The longest lasting cells in your body live up to about 5 years (as implied by the video). Your body recognises this and deals with it by throwing them away. Entropy. The organic matter in our bodies suffers strongly from entropy, more so than ink used for tattoos. So our bodies have adapted to replace matter that has suffered from a critical amount of entropy. If all the matter around a tattoo "died" at roughly the same time, the tattoo would likely fall off with it. The process however is slow and random enough that this is not likely to happen.

Your body replaces the living cells (made up of atoms) that are around the atoms that make up the ink in a tattoo. Just like if break your leg and you have a titanium rod put in, the titanium atoms in the rod will not be replaced but the cells that make up your living tissue around it will. In short it's only the atoms that make up living tissue that replace themselves in your body.

That's obvious. When you're bored, it will feel longer because you have nothing to do, for example talk to anyone. When you're having fun, time flies because you do so much. And when you have done a lot of stuff the day before, you will remember it as a long day, when memories of that day appear.

Everytime a cell undergoes mitosis (replication) it's telomeres get shorter (due to the fact that the lagging strand of DNA is not fully copied in each cycle). Telomeres are repeating sequences of DNA (TTAGGG in humans) which act as a safeguard against this so your chromosomes don't get damaged by the lack of complete replication. Over many cycles the telomeres eventually run out and cells are unable to be replaced correctly (hence ageing). It's obviously more complicated, but thats a summary

Inducing nostalgia through music was something explored by German composers in the Romantic era [c. 1800-1850].
Most notably, Schumann in character pieces for piano [such as in Carnival, op. 9] would bring in themes from other character pieces in a misty, "nostalgic" way, writing notes to the performer pointing them out. Also he would gradually remove one note at a time from a musical phrase, eventually fading away leaving only the "memory" of the phrase. All quite fascinating.

Everything within us runs on chemo/electric bio-circuits. Our "system" is replaced approximately every 5 years. The chemicals which our bodies create become less effective as we age because the atomic/molecular bonds begin to break down with the passage of time. In other words, we become a copy of a copy of a copy etc. until that last copy we use until our dieing day has all the imperfections of the previous copies but magnified greater. That's why we change in our physical selves through time.

Nostalgia, for me, is often visually stimulated, too. As I get older, I find nostalgia hitting me more and more. It's like small snippets or vignette scenes that play out in my mind and have no particular relevance or eventful occurrences. It's just a flash or a few short seconds of a scene that happened long ago playing back in a loop (like those Ear Worms) mentioned. They're kind of depressing and not very pleasurable at all. It's a harsh reminder of time I'll never see again.

When you doing keying (green-screening) there's a fine line along the edges of the person in the first edit - that is, the small fibers of hair, fabric from your shirt, etc, sort of "bleed" over the green, and in the initial cut-away, there's a very thing green line around your whole outside. The quickest way is just to say "let's just fade that line out" - they basically take away a couple of pixels off the edge and fade that line so it's not super-hard.

Because when you hear your own voice when speaking, you are not listening purely through your ears, but partially through your skull.  Your skull is a resonating chamber through which your voice reverberates.  When you record and play it back, you are hearing only through your ears.  That's also why your speaking voice sounds different when you speak with headphones or earplugs on.  You are cutting out the hearing with the ears sounds and hearing only in your head.

I actually asked my friend (he's had tattoos for quite some time).
Black ink never goes away if you don't mess with it.
For example, women with tattoos on their legs will eventually have to get it redone because shaving your leg takes off a thin layer of skin each time, which eventually causes it to fade a bit.
Colored ink will fade because it's broken down over time, which means it has to eventually be redone.
But black ink will last.

Well, all the stuff that's part of your living body gets old or damaged and needs to be replaced; our bodies are in a constant state of repair. It's a process that gets instigated by our bodies themselves. A tattoo isn't a living part of your body, and your body doesn't particularly see the ink as an invader (as it does with infection), so it lies outside of that repair cycle. Though tattoos do fade over time, probably due to losing atoms that do get carried along in the body's repair process.

Simply put, because it is mathematically undefined. Using calculus, its possible to find the limit of the indeterminate form zero over zero using L'Hopital's rule. However, since this is dependent upon the derivative of both the top and the bottom, it depends on what the functions on the top and bottom are. gets closer to 0, the result a/b, gets larger and larger. So as b tends towards 0, the answer (or, the limit) seems to be infinity. But it's important to note that the limit is POSITIVE infinity. If we came from the other side (a/-2, a/-1, a/-0.5...), then the limit tends towards NEGATIVE infinity. So that's means 
for the equation a/0=0 you have 2 results and not one, so the limit "does not exist" and that's probably a better reason why you can't divide by zero.

so any memory you have from more than five years ago is not being retrieved from the cells it was recorded on.  Data parity/copying errors would explain why memories fade and become distorted and links to "lost" memories would be broken until you come across a trigger that still has a link to the "lost" memory.   The brain would obviously need a mechanism to deal with these gaps, false memories would simply be taking advantage of this mechanism.

Memory loss occurs when existing brain cells are damaged/destroyed.
